Derek,

I sense there is "over-emphasis" on the definition of the word evolution in this conversation. 
That said, here goes...


I both strongly agree and mildly disagree with what you have asserted.  ;^)

I would start with agreement - When placing the notion of evolution in a "volitional
consciousness" metaphor, it seems logically consistent to state "...And that's all evolution is. 
No intent.  No direction."  It seems obvious to me "evolution" (a vastly simplified notion
describing a supremely complex highly parallel massively distributed non-deterministic phenomenon)
has no appearance of being "guided" by some meta-evolutionary system.

The system just is.  It has components.  The components have some affinities for other components.
 Some of the components interoperate closely, and others distantly.  All sorts of "grossly
simplified" scientific explanations using causality (again, a vast oversimplification to
demonstrate some degree if higher probability in predicting outcomes) can be had to describe this
unintended and undirected process.  It is breathtaking how beautifully complex and consistent the
system seems to be and behave.


As for my disagreement - Evolution may remain an unintended process  I feel this just describes
its origins.  However, I do not think it can be said accurately it remains undirected.

Once homo-sapien became verbally capable and followed very shortly, at least in geological time
frames, symbolically capable, evolution started being mildly guided (as opposed to undirected). 
And with the discover of genetics, DNA and then biotech, evolution is now more strongly guided
process and will remain so unless humans (or automatic reproductive entities utilizing symbolic
processing) are eliminated.  The domain and lineage of volitionally conscious symbolic thought is
itself remarkably similar to that of DNA and genetics.  There is a new fields, mimetics (rhymes
with genetics), which strives to describe the "evolution" of symbolic thought in terms similiar to
that of genetics.

I think evolution (and eventually even its fundamental definition) is forever altered (and
directed) by the emergence of mimetics.

Just as a rudimentary philosophy is directly depended upon basic psychology, and advanced
psychology is dependent upon the rudementary philosophy, in a continuous upwards cycle (called a
"strange loop" by Dr. Hoffstadtler), I think genetics and mimetics are a form of strange loop.

I think Hofstadler's work "Godel, Escher, Bach: Eternal Golden Braid" does a fantastic job
demonstrating the notions of self-referentiality, emergence, strange loops and demonstrating
Godel's central premise of the "incompleteness" of a system's (and thereby a word's) definition as
closed (or complete).

Given homo-sapien's very small time present as a species, we certainly has dramatically impacted
evolution here on the third rock out from Sol.  And now that we can reason about the "concept"
evolution, we will continue to further harness and exploit it and use it for the powerful tool it
is.  Why?  Because we are tool fixated organisms.  And we like feeling powerful!  :^)

And I *LOVE* being a powerful tool fixated organism!


Jim O'Flaherty


--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
> Well actually the most widely-accepted definition of
> evolution is simply a change in the frequency of genes
> in a population.  Evolution is not inherently
> directional; it is simply change.
> 
> And change could easily be demonstrated in NEAT
> without a fitness function.  Given a population of 100
> individuals, 20% could simply be randomly selected to
> produce offspring via the NEAT mating method, which
> would then be subject to NEAT's mutation operators,
> refilling the population to its original size.  20%
> could then be randomly selected to survive into the
> next generation...and so on.
> 
> Even with no fitness function, the population will
> evolve.  That is, the gene frequencies of the final
> generation will be different from the original
> population (just how different will depend on
> parameter settings, such as mutation rates).
> 
> And that's all evolution is.  No intent.  No
> direction.
> 
> Of course, for our purposes, we want the change to go
> in a particular direction, to optimize a particular
> behavior or set of behaviors, and we try to tailor a
> fitness function that we think best captures the
> features of those behaviors.  We're interested in
> directional change.
> 
> But strictly speaking, biological evolution is not.
> 
> Derek
